hawaiian_text: I ia wā, noke aku ana ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ka  huhuki ā pau kekahi māla ‘uala ā luna o kekahi  māla ‘uala, pēlā nō ka huhuki ‘ana ā pau nā māla  ‘elua ā kū ke āhua o ka lau o ka ‘uala, he kanahā  āhua ka nui o nā māla ‘elua. A laila, ho‘i a‘ela ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o a hō‘ā i ke ahi a ‘ōhinu akula ‘ehā  ‘au o ka ‘uala i luna o kapuahi e ‘ā ana. Iā ia e  ‘ōhinu ana i luna o ke ahi, ho‘i maila kona makua  kāne kōlea ā hiki, nīnau akula i kona makuahine, iā  Pōka‘ī: “‘A‘ole.” ‘Ī aku ‘o Puali‘i: “‘Ae, ‘o ke po‘o  ona a me nā maka ka mea e ‘īna‘i ai ku‘u ‘uala i  kēia lā, no laila, eia kona lā e make ai ia‘u.”
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: At that time, Nāmakaokapāoʻo went and destroyed all of one sweet potato patch and another, in the same manner, destroying the two patches until only the tops of the sweet potato leaves were left, and the appearance of the leaves was like that of a kanahā bird, and the number of the two patches was great. Then, Nāmakaokapāoʻo returned and lit a fire and burned forty sweet potatoes on top of a kapuahi oven that was burning. As he was burning them on top of the fire, his father, a Cassandra-like prophet, arrived, and asked his mother, Pōkaʻī: "Not so?" Pualiʻi replied: "Yes, his head and eyes are the things that my sweet potatoes will be eaten with today, and so, this is the day that he will die."

**Paragraph 6:** 
• This passage continues to illustrate the destructive nature of **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo** (the eyes of the pāoʻo fish), who is still a child but exhibits behavior that is far from childish: 
  – He destroys two entire sweet potato patches, leaving only the tops of the leaves, which are likened to the appearance of a **kanahā** bird, a metaphor that might allude to the destructive consequences of his actions, and the great number of patches destroyed emphasizes the severity of his destructive behavior.
  – The use of **kanahā**, a bird known for itsattachment to the land and its role in Hawaiian mythology, might imply that the destruction caused by **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo** has repercussions that affect the land and the community.
• The number forty, mentioned in the context of burning sweet potatoes, is a significant number in Hawaiian culture, often associated with completion, abundance, and spiritual growth: 
  – In this context, the burning of forty sweet potatoes might symbolize the destruction of abundance and the disregard for spiritual growth, underscoring **Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo**'s reckless behavior.
  – The act of burning sweet potatoes can also be seen as a form of desecration, given the importance of sweet potatoes as a staple crop in Hawaiian culture, particularly during the 'Ai Kapu era, when the cultivation and distribution of food were heavily regulated by religious and social norms.
• The dialogue between **Pōkaʻī** (perhaps 'night falls upon the high chief') and **Pualiʻi** (a name that might be associated with the sweet potato, **ʻuala**, and the concept of growth or increase) reveals the tension and conflict within the family: 
  – **Pualiʻi**'s threat to eat **Nāmakaokapāoʻo**'s head and eyes with sweet potatoes is a stark and violent image, which might be interpreted as a symbolic expression of the consequences of **Nāmakaokapāoʻo**'s actions, rather than a literal threat.
  – The mention of head and eyes as the means to eat sweet potatoes alludes to the Hawaiian cultural practice of using the head and eyes of the **ulua** fish as a substitute for human sacrifice, highlighting the idea that **Nāmakaokapāoʻo**'s behavior is seen as a form of sacrilegious destruction, worthy of punishment.
• The character of **Nāmakaokapāoʻo** can be seen as an allegory for the forces of change and progress, which are often at odds with traditional practices and norms: 
  – His destructive behavior might symbolize the dismantling of the 'Ai Kapu system, which was characterized by strict rules and regulations governing the cultivation, distribution, and consumption of food.
  – The conflict between **Nāmakaokapāoʻo** and **Pualiʻi** might represent the tension between the old and the new, with **Nāmakaokapāoʻo** embodying the spirit of change and **Pualiʻi** representing the adherence to traditional norms and practices.

reference_translation: At that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o was busy tearing  apart the sweet potato patches, yanking them out.  He tore apart both sweet potato patches until  there rose a mound of sweet potato leaves, forty  mounds in all from the two patches. Then  Nāmakaokapāo‘o went back and lit a fire to broil  four sweet potato vines on a fire pit. As he was  broiling the vines, wilting them, his stepfather  came back and reached him and asked   Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s mother, Pōka‘ī, and she said,  “No.” Puali‘i said, “Yes, his head and eyes as food  to go with the sweet potatoes that I’ll eat today.  So, today I will kill him.”
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 6:**• The numbers referred to in this paragraph are  interesting and likely a riddle to solve, with esoteric  meaning: 2, 4, 40\. Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is a child, but  behaves like a mature adult, albeit destructive and  spiteful, but calculating. This has allegorical meaning  and likely relates to wastefulness and the need to  dismantle ‘Ai Kapu practices.  • Pua-li‘i was so enraged by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s  destruction of the sweet potato patches that he  threatened to eat his head (po‘o) and eyes (nā maka)  with sweet potato in place of ulua fish. The head of  the ulua or of a person likely represents the sweet  potato tuber and the eyes likely represent the sweet  potato vine cutting (maka) that is used to replant and  perpetuate the crop, symbolically, the people of the  land. This also explains the meaning of ʻmaka’ in the  name, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o, with ʻpāo‘o’ being used  as a poetic reference to ʻpo‘o’ (head).  – Ulua was used as a substitute for human sacrifice  on the heiau in the ‘Ai Kapu culture (footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1986:369) *ulua*: “This fish was substituted for human sacrifices when the latter were not available , probably because of word magic and the meaning of *ulua 2* \[to grow/increase; to be possessed by a god\]. Since an *ulua* replaces a man, *ulua* also means “man, sweetheart,” especially in love songs.”). In this case,  Pua-li‘i threatens to eat the human head and eyes  of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o in place of the ulua: the  opposite of normal ‘Ai Kapu custom. This appears  to allude to Pua-li‘i’s holding on to the ‘Ai Kapu  customs, going back in time allegorically, rather  than forward in time, where humans are no longer  sacrificed in the Western culture. Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o, on the other hand, represents going forward in time, a time of progressive thinking and   abandonment of the ‘Ai Kapu;
